column4: I just got a 4 processor (P3 all around xeon) and it has 4 SCSI HD's (6 available slots) and 1 OS Controller HD that is IDE.  Has CDRW etc etc etc.  It has Windows 2000 Server pre-loaded but I keep getting a STOP! error on it.  I went to install Ubuntu Server Text Install and it keeps freezing when the system goes to Partition Manager.  I think the server install is for one processor, but was told I could install the controller afte
Your text was cut after ", but was told I could install the controller afte"
... but was told I could install the controller afterward.  Any Ideas on this?
Any ideas?
Nope. It would help to know which chipset your controller is using. Try running lspci (if you're in linux).
I can't even get to the windows command prompts, so no, i can't do that either.
should BIOS boot-up display that?
I really do not know or think so.
Have you got the name of the motherboard?
lemme check and ill get back to you asap
i have it in the room next door
It's not showing anything...motherboard wise.
Now let me see if I got this right. The disk controller is it on the motherboard or is it an expansion card?
That really did not answer my quetsion. The question is if the server has got the SCSI controller buildt in on the motherboard or if it is an expansion card that sits in a PCI slot.
It's on the motherboard

I see. Have you got any chance at all to open the chassis of the server and have a look-see on the motherboard in question to determine the producer and model? Perhaps you've got this information in any manuals that may have accompanied the server?
If the server is prebuildt who buildt it and what did they call the server?
I have opened the server to look for a model/producer, but can't find anything.
the manufacturer built it, but no software/docs/anything with it, just called it a server
Actually they called it a ProServ
Whi manufactured it? And has it got a number after ProServ?
I've found a manual for proserv 900, 1200 and 1500 servers. There should probably be one that indicates which of these you've got.
Actually it goes all the way up to 5000 :)
and as far as I can tell the manufacturer is Tangent
You still there?
I'm back sorry about that.
I'm going to go check again, make sure I didn't miss the manufacturer name.
I am guessing Tangent Computer ProServ 3000 with four 550MHz Xeon processors and six hot-swappable drives and six pci and one isa slot.
guess is based on
Seems like an old piece of equiptment tbh. :)
however on tangent.com I find no reference to the proserv series so finding the hardware is probably a matter of looking on it.
the cable on the SCSI has a tag on the side that connects to the motherboard. says FoxCONN  probably the cable maker or something.
Yes. I am looking for the name of the motherboard. I've been all trough the tangent.com website and found various proserv owners manuals but none of them list anythign useful.
You might want to contact tangent on http://www.tangent.com/explore/tech/support.htm they do list that they provide "Lifetime technical support"
I suggest that you ask them for all technical spesifications on the Proserv 3000 and wether or not it was ever shipped with support for P3 processors.
Also they need a serial number which should be printed on the chasis somwhere. Perhaps near the power supply, perhaps somwhere else.
hmmm. I can't find a name on the motherboard. The chips have different names on them, (the ones soldered onto the board.) NEC, INTEL, and LSI
Now, judging by the look and feel of the tangent.com website I wouldn't get my hopes up.
There are a couple places i have seen S/N's but they aren't labeled...all on the chasis
The name I am looking for should not be on any chip. It should be written on the motherboard itself.
Common places are near the processor seat (in your case there's four) and near the pins where the cables from the front panel of the chasis are plugged (for hdd and power lights and such)
there is a sticker on the processor bays that says SMP/PORTLAND
No, that's not it. SMP = Something Multiple Pocessors or something.
What you could do is google the names and numbers on the chips near the SCSI connectors. One of them will probably be the SCSI controller chip.
Now how new is this server btw?
Is this server in a regular chasis or is it for rack mounting?
Regular chasis...its short (height) and long (depth) and about as wide as it is tall
i wouldn't be surprised if it were an older system
about as wide as it is tall? And appox how many centimeter is that?
18tall x12wide x25depth
That would be a shuttle chassis, wouldn't it?
shuttle?
something like http://global.shuttle.com/Product/images/SB95Pv2_Top.jpg ?
Nope.. Its IVORY (white) not black, has a air door in front that swings open and the drives can be removed that way... and you can access floppy/cdrom then
I was thinking about the form factor.
oooh. in that case, yes
Ok. Well that will make it a newer model than what I was concidering. :)
oh.
those cases and the mobos for them aren't all that old
okay.
where the SCSI connectors are, it says NSCO
where the SCSI connectors are, it says NSCI
I THINK I FOUND IT! :D
http://america.hongfaith.com/Case_Chassis/Server%20Chassis/cabrillo-c.htm
http://www.dealtime.co.uk/xPF-Intel_Cabrillo_C_Server_Chassis_KCYCABRAL
Those look like regular mini towers and not shuttle cases tbh.
it looks just like the one i have, which is a server case, not regular.
Intel Cabrillo-C Server Chassis
you still there?
working :)
oh okay.
so you have no clue either?
I've been looking for possible matches for baby atx motherboards with quad P3 socket 370
Oh...okay
so far the only quad boards of that form factor have been for AMD processors. :/
Still it would amaze me if the name and model of the mobo wasn't printed on the mobo itself.
Have you got a digital camera? Could you take a picture of the mobo and send it to me?
it's not and yes, can you get DCC;s thru chat?
I think that port should be open.
try it.
alternately you can publish it on esnips.com or photobucket.com (registration required)
i just took them, sendin now
The requests are getting to me just fine but I am unable to connect to your machine to initiate the transfer.
You need to open up some ports to allow dcc file transfers.
np. :)
You could always email them to me.
You auto-replied me. :p
oh...
I must have closed that window by mistake. Please /msg the url again. :)
You have PM
ehh.. no I don't o.O
you need to PM me first, i am unregged here... so you have to initiate contacty
LOL i will reg
I'm back Paging BlueEagle:
Paging BlueEagle to DCC please :)
